Body:
There are many studies on calligraphy, and in some cultures (Chinese, Indic, Arabic) it became a really significant part of culture.

However, there are not only examples of good handwriting. Often we see examples of bad handwritten script. There are even anecdotes of "doctor's handwriting" that can't be easily deciphered (no offense).

Sometimes even a nicely written text may become difficult to read:

Also, it is well known that Latin i obtained a dot above specifically because it was hard to read it in Gothic script of 14th century:

I've never found any researches of this topic. So, can anyone please explain and/or point me on some researches about:

  • Why people who are equally educated and familiar with the language may be able or unable to read a badly written hand script?
  • Are there any special mechanisms involved when we read handwritten texts, compared to reading a printed text?
  • How one can improve their ability to read handwritten text? (besides just practicing)
Title: Deciphering a handwritten script
